natural problem: My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella?
natural solution: In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$

Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.

\begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\

\frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_time friend_reading_time :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_time = 2"
and h1 : "friend_reading_time = my_reading_time / 3"
shows  "60 * friend_reading_time = 40" (* minutes *)
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_time friend_reading_time :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_time = 2"
and h1 : "friend_reading_time = my_reading_time / 3"
shows  "60 * friend_reading_time = 40" (* minutes *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem: If I read for 2 hours and my friend reads for a third of the time I read, how many minutes does my friend read? The final answer is 40 minutes.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_speed friend_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_speed = my_speed / 3"
and h1 : "my_speed * 2 = 1"
shows  "friend_speed * time = 40 / 60" (* convert minutes to hours *)
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_speed friend_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_speed = my_speed / 3"
and h1 : "my_speed * 2 = 1"
shows  "friend_speed * time = 40 / 60" (* convert minutes to hours *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: If your friend is cycling at a speed one third of your speed, and you are cycling at a speed of 0.5 miles per hour, how long would your friend take to travel 40 miles? The answer is 60 hours.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "my_reading_speed = 2 * 60"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "my_reading_speed = 2 * 60"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem: If my friend reads at a speed three times faster than mine, and I read at a speed of 2 pages per minute, how fast does my friend read? The final answer is 40 pages per minute.

a_3.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_speed = 2 * 60"
and h1 : "friend_reading_speed = my_reading_speed / 3"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"  (* friend will take 40 minutes to read the novella *)
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_speed = 2 * 60"
and h1 : "friend_reading_speed = my_reading_speed / 3"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"  (* friend will take 40 minutes to read the novella *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem: "If I can read a novella in 2 hours, and my friend reads at a speed that is one third of mine, how long in minutes will it take my friend to read the novella? The answer is 40 minutes."

a_4.formal problem:
theorem
fixes friend_rate my_rate :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_rate = 3 * my_rate"
and h1 : "my_rate = 1 / 120"
shows  "friend_rate = 1 / 40"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes friend_rate my_rate :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_rate = 3 * my_rate"
and h1 : "my_rate = 1 / 120"
shows  "friend_rate = 1 / 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem: If my friend reads three times faster than me and my reading rate is 1 page per 120 seconds, what is my friend's reading rate in pages per second? The final answer is 1 page per 40 seconds.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "2 * my_reading_speed = novella_length"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\

 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "2 * my_reading_speed = novella_length"
shows  "friend_reading_speed = 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: If my friend reads three times faster than me, and I can read a novella at twice my reading speed, how fast does my friend read if the novella is 40 units long? The answer is 40 units.

a_6.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_speed friend_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_speed = my_speed / 3"
and h1 : "my_speed * 2 = 1"
shows  "friend_speed * 1 = 40 / 60" (* How many hours it takes my friend to read the same novella *)
a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_speed friend_speed :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_speed = my_speed / 3"
and h1 : "my_speed * 2 = 1"
shows  "friend_speed * 1 = 40 / 60" (* How many hours it takes my friend to read the same novella *)
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: If I can read a novella in half an hour (0.5 hours), and my friend reads at a speed one third of mine, how long does it take my friend to read the same novella? The answer is 40 minutes (or 2/3 of an hour).

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_time :: real 
and friend_reading_time :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_time = 2 * 60"
and h1 : "friend_reading_time = my_reading_time / 3"
shows  "friend_reading_time = 40"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_time :: real 
and friend_reading_time :: real
assumes h0 : "my_reading_time = 2 * 60"
and h1 : "friend_reading_time = my_reading_time / 3"
shows  "friend_reading_time = 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem: Assume that I read a book for 2 hours and my friend reads the same book three times faster than me. How long does it take my friend to read the book? The final answer is 40 minutes.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
and my_time friend_time :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "my_time = 2 * 60"
and h2 : "my_reading_speed * my_time = friend_reading_speed * friend_time"
shows  "friend_time = 40"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes my_reading_speed friend_reading_speed :: real
and my_time friend_time :: real
assumes h0 : "friend_reading_speed = 3 * my_reading_speed"
and h1 : "my_time = 2 * 60"
and h2 : "my_reading_speed * my_time = friend_reading_speed * friend_time"
shows  "friend_time = 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem: A friend reads at a speed that is three times my reading speed. If I read for 2 hours, and we both read the same amount of material, how much time does my friend need to read the same material? The final answer is 40 minutes.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes you your_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * you = 3 * your_friend"
and h1 : "2 * 60 * you = 1 * novella"
shows  "your_friend * novella = 40"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 My friend reads three times as fast as I do. If it takes me 2 hours to read a novella, how many minutes will it take my friend to read the same novella? The final Answer is 40\text{ min}
 ### Proof
 In reading, $\text{speed}=\frac{\text{amount of material}}{\text{time}}.$ Let the amount of material in the novella be $N.$ So $\text{speed}=\frac{N}{\text{time}}.$ Also, it is a good idea to convert hours to minutes since the answer should be in minutes: $2hrs=2\cdot 60min= 120min.$
 Knowing that my friend reads three times as fast as I do, we can set up a proportion of our speeds: $$\frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}=3.$$And now we can use the formula above to proceed.
 \begin{align} \frac{\text{my friend's speed}}{\text{my speed}}&=3\\ \frac{\frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}}{\frac{N}{120\text{ min}}}&=3\\ \frac{N}{\text{my friend's time}}\cdot\frac{120\text{ min}}{N}&=3\\
 \frac{N\cdot 120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}\cdot N}&=3\\ \frac{120\text{ min}}{\text{my friend's time}}&=3\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\frac{120\text{ min}}{3}\\ \text{my friend's time}&=\boxed{40\text{ min}}.
 \end{align}
 *)

theorem
fixes you your_friend :: real
assumes h0 : "1 * you = 3 * your_friend"
and h1 : "2 * 60 * you = 1 * novella"
shows  "your_friend * novella = 40"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: "If it takes you one third the time it takes your friend to read a page, and you can read a novella in two hours, how long does it take your friend to read the novella? The final answer is 40 hours."
